msItem.title: Devotion to the Seven Last Words, attributed to Bede
msItem.rubric: Incipit oratio uenerabilis bede presbiteri de qua ut fertur qui cotidie et deuote flexis genibus eam dixerit. nec dyabolus nec mali homines ei nocere poterint nec sine confessione morietur. et per triginta dies ante obitum suum uidebit gloriosam uirginem mariam in auxilio sibi preparatam
msItem.incipit: Domine ihesu christe qui septem uerba die ultimo uite tue in cruce pendens dixisti
msItem.explicit: Veni ut mecum sedeas cum angelis meis sanctis in regno meo epulari iocundari et commorari. Per infinita seculorum secula Amen.

msItem.title: Prayer with indulgence of Boniface VI
msItem.rubric: Cuilibet dicenti hanc orationem inter eleuationem corporis christi et tercium Agnus dominus papa bonifacium vius concessit duo milia annorum indulgentiarum ad supplicationem philippi regis francie
msItem.incipit: Domine ihesu christe qui hanc sacratissimam carnem tuam et preciosum carnem tuam et preciosum sanguinem tuum de gloriose uirginis marie utero assumpsisti
msItem.explicit: et ab uniuersis malis presentibus preteritis et futuris. Amen.
msItem.note: Cf. Hore beate virginis marie ad usum Sarum [Wolf. Hopyl?] Pro Anthonio Vérard, Paris 1503-5, fols. 17v-18r.

Letter(s?) of Christ to Abgar, mingled with devotions to Christ and the cross. (The divisions between the texts are uncertain, and some of the devotions may be intended as part of the letter(s).) For the letter cf. Stegmüller 147,1a; the text here is a longer version in which the letter is given apotrophaic powers; cf. D. C. Skemer, Binding Words: Textual Amulets in the Middle Ages (2006) pp. 96-105.

msItem.rubric: (fol. 252r) Hec est epistola manu saluatoris conscripta regi indie abagaro per angelum erat transmissa ut in legenda aurea asseritur et uallet contra omnes impugnationes tam spirituales quam corporales
msItem.incipit: (fol. 252r) Hec est epistola domini nostri ihesu christi quam manu sua scripsit mittens per angelum ad agabarum regem indie
msItem.explicit: (fol. 252v) nec alique alia creatura ei nocere potent illo die

msItem.incipit: (fol. 252v) Crux christi sit semper mecum Crux christi est quam adoro
msItem.explicit: (fol. 253r) Crux christi sit semper ante me post me quia antiquus hostis fugit ubi uidet te
msItem.note: Similar to the text pr. in Reliquiae Hearnianae, ed. P. Bliss, I (1857), 196-7

msItem.rubric: (fol. 253r) Hic incipit alia epistola domini nostri ihesu christi quam manu sua scripsit ad agabarum regem indie dicens
msItem.incipit: Hec est epistola mea beatus es agabar rex qui in die me non uidisti et in me credidisti
msItem.explicit: (fol. 253v) et saluus ens in ciuitate in domo in uia in agro in mare et ubicumque fueris

msItem.incipit: (fol. 254r) Benedicat me imperialis maiestas Protegat me regalis diuinitas
msItem.explicit: (fol. 254r) saluus et protectio In nomine patris et filij et spiritus sancti Amen
msItem.note: Largely as pr. Horae Eboracenses, p. 88.

msItem.incipit: (fol. 254v) O bone ihesu o dulcissime ihesu o piissime ihesu
msItem.explicit: (fol. 256r) et omnes qui diligunt nomen tuum quod est ihesus
msItem.note: Cf. the text printed Leroquais, Livres d'Heures, II.345.

msItem.incipit: (fol. 256r) Posui deum adiutorem meum. Dominus michi adiutor non timebo quid faciat mihi homo. Illumina domine oculus meos neunquam obdormiam in morte
msItem.explicit: (fol. 256v) et improuisa morte et ab omnibus periculis me defendat. Amen.

msItem.title: Fifteen Joys of the Virgin, in French
msItem.note: Sonet, no. 458; cf. text pr. Leroquais, Livres d'Heures II.310-11.

msItem.title: Seven Requests to our Lord, in French
msItem.incipit: Dous dieux dous pere sainte trinite vn dieu biaus sires dieux ie vous requier conseil et aide
msItem.explicit: et me octroie par ton plaisir que ie puisse confes morir. Pater noster.
msItem.note: Sonet, no. 504; cf. text pr. Leroquais, Livres d'Heures II.309-10.

binding.p: Purple velvet with gilt corner pieces, English, 16th century.

history.provenance: A kneeling figure of a man is in the miniatures of St George (44v) and St Christopher (48v), the male form of address occurs on fol.232v, but a female owner is suggested on fols. 61v, 232, and 247vs.
Henry VII (?): referred to as 'Henrici Septimi breviarium' by John Rouse in 1620 (Titus Livius Forojuliensis, ed. T. Hearne (1726), p. 201).
Henry VIII (?): traditionally said to have belonged to him (W. D. Macray, Annals of the Bodleian (1890), p. 468).
history.acquisition: Acquired before 1615, probably purchased between 1602 and 1605 with part of £50 given by lord Cobham.
